content: The "Youth Violence Prevention Act of 1999" prohibits violent juvenile offenders from possessing firearms or ammunition. The "Youth Violence Prevention Act of 1999" prohibits violent juvenile offenders from possessing firearms or ammunition. An amendment to Section 921(a)(20) of title 18, United States Code, defines 'act of violent juvenile delinquency' as an adjudication of delinquency for committing an act before the age of eighteen that would be a serious violent felony if committed by an adult. The amendment to Section 921(a)(20) of title 18, United States Code, clarifies that what constitutes a conviction of a crime or an adjudication of an act of violent juvenile delinquency is determined by the law of the jurisdiction where the proceedings took place. Expunged, set aside, pardoned, or restored convictions or adjudications of violent juvenile delinquency are not considered as such. The amendment to Section 922 of title 18, United States Code prohibits individuals who have committed an act of violent juvenile delinquency from possessing firearms. The amendment to Section 922 of title 18, United States Code prohibits individuals who have committed an act of violent juvenile delinquency from possessing firearms. This provision applies to adjudications of violent juvenile delinquency occurring after a specified date, when records of such adjudications are available in the national instant criminal background check system. SEC. 3. STRAW PURCHASE PENALTIES. Straw Purchase Penalties: Amends Section 924(a)(2) of title 18, United States Code to impose fines and imprisonment up to 10 years for knowingly violating certain subsections of section 922, including selling or transferring a firearm for unlawful purposes. The amendment imposes fines and imprisonment up to 15 years for using a firearm in a violent felony, or up to 20 years if the procurement is for a juvenile. The terms 'violent felony' and 'juvenile' are defined in specific sections of the law. The amendment will take effect 180 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. JUVENILE WEAPONS PENALTIES. Juvenile Weapons Penalties: Amends Section 924(a) of title 18 United States Code to impose fines and imprisonment on juveniles violating section 922(x), with exceptions for probation under certain conditions. Juvenile offenders can face fines and up to 20 years in prison for possessing a handgun, as outlined in Section 924(a) of title 18 United States Code. Exceptions apply if the juvenile has not been convicted of certain offenses. Juveniles can face fines and up to 20 years in prison for possessing a handgun or ammunition in violation of section 922(x)(2) and 922(q) with the intent to commit a violent felony. Others who knowingly violate section 922(x) can be fined, imprisoned for up to 1 year, or both if they sell, deliver, or transfer a handgun or ammunition to a juvenile knowing the potential consequences. Juveniles can face fines and up to 20 years in prison for possessing a handgun or ammunition with intent to commit a violent felony. The term 'violent felony' is defined in section 924(e)(2)(B). Juveniles prosecuted in federal court under this law will be subject to the same sentencing laws and procedures. Juveniles prosecuted in federal court can face fines and up to 20 years in prison for possessing a handgun or ammunition with intent to commit a violent felony. The law prohibits the sale or transfer of handguns or suitable ammunition to juveniles, and also prohibits juveniles from knowingly possessing such items. The law prohibits the sale or transfer of handguns or suitable ammunition to juveniles, except for specific circumstances such as employment, ranching or farming activities, target practice, or hunting. The law prohibits the sale or transfer of handguns or suitable ammunition to juveniles, except for specific circumstances such as employment, ranching or farming activities, target practice, or hunting. Juveniles can possess and use handguns or ammunition for target practice, hunting, or instruction in safe use, with parental consent and in accordance with state and local laws. Juveniles can possess and use handguns or ammunition for specific activities like ranching, farming, target practice, or hunting, with parental consent and in compliance with laws. During transportation, the handgun must be unloaded and in a locked container. Juveniles can possess and use handguns or ammunition with parental approval for specific activities like ranching or farming, inheritance transfer, self-defense against intruders, or if they are members of the Armed Forces. Juveniles can possess handguns or ammunition with parental approval for certain activities. If a juvenile's possession becomes unlawful, the items will be returned to the lawful owner. The term 'juvenile' refers to a person under 18 years old. In a prosecution under this subsection, the court must require the presence of the juvenile's parent or legal guardian. The court can enforce attendance of a parent or guardian for a juvenile defendant in a prosecution under this subsection. The amendment will take effect 180 days after the enactment of the Act.
